reviews.review_header: My garden hose has more power than this thing
reviews.review_text: Warning: I spent loads & loads of time reading all the reviews regarding this power washer. I was really, really excited about the purchase and thrilled at the prospect of being able to handle some outdoor home and fence cleaning projects on my own without hired help! My gardener helped me assemble the unit. When we tried it out, I was bitterly disappointed. The washer has very little power and I think my garden hose - when placed on the "Stream" or "Jet" setting, has more power than this...

The pressure washer [AR383] is shipped from Montreal, Canada. We used it to clean mold from our driveway, sidewalk, street curb, and all concrete-covered areas [altogether 5 hours of operation]. We also used it to clean mold from the bricks of our house exterior walls [again 5 hours of operation]. The amount of mold was huge: this is the Houston shore area, with atrocious heat and humidity, and the mold had been accumulating for 8 years. The washer worked great! The pressure was sufficient to clean the concrete, although at a pace somewhat slower than for a gas-engine washer. The pressure was just right to clean the house wall bricks [unsealed "insulation" bricks, very porous and rather brittle] without damaging them. In fact, the adjustable spray nozzle at focused stream grooved / spalled the brick surface, so we used the turbo-nozzle. Weak points: 1. The recessed water supply inlet and the plastic hose connector [difficult to tighten the connector and to keep the hose from unscrewing itself]. 2. Storage hose reel [rotating drum] diameter is too small, and fast / careless reeling can damage the pressure hose. 3. Winding path for the electrical cable cannot hold it; we extended the cable path to over the washer's handle. However, these are minor issues. [And I notice them because I am an engineer.] Side note: Contrary to what salesmen might tell you, the turbo-nozzle does NOT increase the spray pressure! It lowers the pressure, by extracting energy from the water in order to turn the turbine that moves the spray nozzle [thence "turbo-nozzle"]. To get peak pressure, use the adjustable nozzle at focused stream.
Worked well for a couple of uses in one season. Dead the next. Hose leaked, engine tripped breakers. Not happy with this product.

So far I rate this machine as better than expected, knowing the history of many electric pressure washers.

reviews.review_header: The cheap plastic will drive you nuts
reviews.review_text: We listened to most of the reviewers here ordering this washer a week ago and I was hopefully optimistic we'd be spraying away to our hearts content over the Holiday. Sadly the ground fault interrupter plug didn't work on our AR Power Washer, so we couldn't really try it out. Additionally, the quick release coupling joining our hose to the pressure washer is made of the CHEAPEST POSSIBLE PLASTIC. One side is actually threaded for a pipe fitting rather than a hose. It immediately stripped when we tried making it work on the hose. As others have already stated, that problem is solved by going to your local hardware, replacing it with a brass quick connect. For us that was 3 fittings at $5 each. Does anyone else out there think spending $150-$180 on this washer is enough to expect a good quality brass fitting --that actually "fits"-- to be included?? Nevertheless, I was preconditioned to buying brass fittings to begin with based on other reviewers. Unfortunately, our problems continued. Apparently the "ground fault interrupter" built in to the plug was kaput-- it kept popping its little breaker no matter what we did or where it was plugged in. Based on that we decided it was best to pack it all back up (an arduous & disappointing task) and ship it back to Amazon. Thankfully, Amazon's return policy on merchandise coming from their distribution center is outstanding. Two hours after the fiasco started we dropped our AR Power Washer off at UPS, returning it prepaid by Amazon. Then we migrated on to pick out a replacement at Home Depot. OTHER THOUGHTS: After we purchased and unpacked a Homelite pressure washer replacement from the Depot, I noticed a few more things I pass on for you to for consideration. The AR really feels like a pile of cheap plastic next to a similar Homelite model. -The wheels are plastic (Homelites are rubber), -the frame is plastic (Homelite's is tubular steel), -The fittings are almost all plastic (Homelite's are brass), -the hose is lighter gauge (Homelite's is much better nylon), -The hose reel is useless (Homelite had a functional velcro tie strap) -the spray gun is flimsier than the Homelite as well -The electrical switches and plugs are less sturdy than the Homelite. It was immediately clear to me as soon as we opened the box that the Homelite (at a similar price) was much, much more solidly constructed. Finally, I'd just like to say our new replacement worked out of the box with no monkeying around at the hardware store. So, my advice. Do not buy this model AR Power Washer. And if you're reading this Amazon, I'd start carrying the Homelite (or similar) product line instead of AR if you want to cut back on the returns. I have to say something I rarely do-- the AR is junk. I am NOT saying this Homelite (the Homelite Electric 1700 PSI HyrdoSurge Pressure Washer) is fabulous or anything, I'm just saying in comparison, it is much better constructed. It seems to work fairly well on our deck etc so far, so we're happy.

Unit worked well for about 10 minutes but then began to smell burnt plastic and noticed smoke coming out of the unit. Immediately shut off and didn't use for acouple of days. Then unit would not even turn back on. I can also echo the comments regarding the fitting between the water source and the unit...it's almost comical how much water sprays out of the fitting once you turn the water on. reviews.review_text: My husband and I decided to try out our new pressure washer and clean off a cement patio. At first it seemed to work great, but after about 10 minutes it lost pressure. After a few more minutes smoke started pouring from the motor and there was a strong noxious electrical burning smell. We contacted the vendor as indicated in the manual, but they just told us to read the instruction manual. Somehow I don't think the instruction manual was going to fix a bad motor. The other option they gave us was to PAY to ship it to them and they would repair it. That seemed to be incredibly poor customer service considering the product was faulting from the beginning. We just sent it back to Amazon instead, and kudos to Amazon for having such an easy return policy.

reviews.review_header: Better than Karcher but don't expect pro results
reviews.review_text: This washer works great--with limitations, for a while. Then I lent it to a friend (pretty much had to, to keep said friend happy) and it came back DOA. And--don't expect pro results on a huge house or driveway. This is a small, electrically powered home unit and for what it's intended, it does well. Try anything big and you'll be disappointed. Good points: Easy enough to use (once you figure out the puzzling instructions.) Good ol' Youtube generally has some show-off giving you a very good tutorial. There are some out there. Does a GREAT job on decks. I washed the algae off our deck railing and it was superior to doing that task with scrub brush and hose. Really got into the crevices of the vinyl railings and took off the green scum. Cleans up boats, cars, small amounts of vinyl siding, sidewalks. If you get that darkened cement from lichens, algae, soot, it will clean it off. Portable, and not too heavy. WAY better than that yellow thing, Karcher. I've never had a Karcher that didn't give up the ghost or fail to do much right out of the gate. This is definitely better. Bad points: Won't do much if you aren't right up close. This is not an industrial powerwasher that the pros use to do your house. It will burn out if you run it longer than (I estimate) fifteen minutes. I warned my borrower, don't run it for long periods of time. It's not designed for that. It heats up. Sure enough, borrower ran it endlessly to clean their sidewalks and it came back (without a word to the wise) dead, dead dead. Yeah, I know what you did there. Moral of story, neither a borrower or lender (of your favorite or expensive tools) be. Bottom line: will do smaller tasks with great ability, but can burn out if you get over-enthusiastic and it won't do a 2 story house or a 100 foot yacht. For that, you have "people."

reviews.review_header: This is the one to buy
reviews.review_text: I did a lot of research on electric power washers and this brand seemed to have really good professional reviews. I chose this particular model because of the long power cord and the long high pressure hose. As extra bonuses you also get 1900 pounds of pressure and everything wraps up nice and neat on the unit. My only concern is the plastic connection for the hose. I wish they would have used brass or steel like what they have on the high pressure connection. I've tested the unit for about three hours. I washed a couple of windows; did a great job. I cleaned my tiled patio; got the dirt out of the grout. I cleaned my car; got most of the dirt, but even a 3000 psi unit can't get it all, it's just a basic fact you have to use some elbow grease to get road scum off. I also tried it on my fence to clean off dirt and moss build up; didn't do such a good job but then again it is a 1900psi unit and for wood you really need at least 2600psi. For that you need a gas unit and I really don't want to deal with the mess, the loud noise, and the maintenance. I'm really happy with this unit so far, I just hope it doesn't break after a couple of uses like I heard from reviewers of other brands.

reviews.review_text: Simply outstanding Pressure washer. See my video for some details. For a good price, you get a powerful small machine that stows quickly and easy. Update August 14, 2013: I am still impressed with this machine. Finished cleaning my entire (very large) deck with no issues. I do have a sense that a gas powered, larger machine might do in one pass what I have to do with two passes on this one. However, the fact that it is so small, light, gas/oil free and easy to stow is a huge advantage over a gas powered one. I would not trade it for a gas one. So after cleaning the deck, proceeded to stain with a Wagner Power Sprayer and Behr stain. Went really well and discovered that the power washer makes cleaning up afterwards so much easier. Instead of brushing various parts I just power washed the paint off. It worked great.
